724963f-a.title: Queens: 2nd Street - Borden Avenue
724963f-a.text:
2nd Street, west side, between Borden and 51st Avenuee, showing the Queens County Bank, a branch of the Corn Exchange
Bank.
P. L. Sperr  October 25, 1936
cg 0  NV2: (2

726166f-a.title: Queens: Borden Avenue - 2nd Street
726166f-a.text:
Borden Avenue, at, and adjoining the N.E. corner of 2nd Street. The corner building, which is now the 34th Street Ferry Storage Warehouse, is the former Miller Hotel, erected by Oliver Charlick, General Manager of the Long Island Railroad, for Tony Miller (Mueller). It was a rendemvous for sportsmen. Richard Croker and Tim Sullivan were guests here. The building was sold in 1917, altered, and then used as a phonograph manufactory. It appears from the photograph that the upper floor is used as living quafters; a saloon occupies the ground floor on the right. The building to the right is an old trolley barn, extending through to
51st Avenue.
P. L. Sperr  October 25, 1936

726165f-a.title: Queens: Borden Avenue - 2nd Street
726165f-a.text:
Borden Avenue, east from 2nd Street. The first two-story building on the left is an old street car barn; in the center of the view is the 4-story Long Asland Railroad branch of the
Y.M.C.A.
P. L. Sperr  October 25, 1936
